Notes for 1-3

XML Database

Wiki Article link

  • An XML Database allows data to be specified and stored in XML format.
  • The data can be querried transformed, exported and returned to a calling system.
  • XML databases are a flavor of document-oriented databases which are in turn a category of NoSQL

Reasons for XML in Databases

There are number of reasons to directly specify data in XML, as opposed to in a relational model.

  • Data may need to be exposed or ingested as XML, so using another format forces doubl-modelling of the data
  • XML is very well suited to sparse data, deeply nested data and mixed content.
  • XML is human readable, whereas relational tables require SQL knowledge to access.
  • In order to store XML data in a relational datababase, the structure of the XML document must first be defined into an equivalent relational model. Each time the data needs to be exported as XML, the XML Document must created from its relational representation.

Native XML databases

  • XML Databases are optimized to work with XML Documents.
  • Native XML databases are especially tailored for working with XML data, utilizing custom optimized data structures for storage and querrying. This improves the performance of both read-only querries and updates.
  • Standard tools for querrying and transforming XML exist, that utilize the metadata:
    • XQuery: The standard functional querry langauge for querrying and transforming XML data.
    • XPath: A sub-language of XQuery that supports it.
    • XSLT: A language specifically designed for transforming XML documents into other format.

Document-oriented Database

  • wiki article

Document-orinted databases are designed for storing, retrieving and managing document-oriented information, also known as semi-strcutured data, which in turn is a category of NoSQL databases.

Document databases contrast strongly with the RDBes. RDBs generally store data in separate tables defined by the programmer, i.e. a single object may be spread across several tables. Document databases store all information of a given object in a single instance in the database. This eliminates the need for object-relational mapping while loading data into the database.

Semi-structured model

In the semi-structured model there is no separation between the data and the schema.

advantages:

  • some data that cannot be constraiend by a schema can be stored this way.
  • a flexible format for data exchange between different types of databases.
  • data is stored in a human-readable format.
  • the schema can easily be changed.

disadvantages

  • querries cannot be made as efficiently as in a more constraied structure such as in the relational model.

Documents

Documents are the central concept of a document-oriented DB and correspond to the programming concept of an object. The model assumes that documents encapsulate and encode data (or information) in some standard format or encoding, such as XML, YAML, JSON etc.

Relationship to RDBs
